roles/ensure-ansible/tasks/main.yaml.message:
I'm not entirely convinced this needs to be it's own role since it's just the pip module with pretty much no defaults set.

roles:
  - ensure-ansible

would be the same as:

tasks:
  - pip:
      name: ansible

What I mean is that I can't see anything in the way from doing that as a task in a pre-run since the role adds so little to just using the pip module directly.

This role also has no dependencies towards other roles and no role is directly dependent on it (nothing includes it or uses meta dependencies towards it).

Adding this as a role seems to me like it would be harder to implement a more extensive ensure-ansible role since that would also need to support all of these parameters.

Take a look at ensure-tox for example:
https://opendev.org/zuul/zuul-jobs/src/branch/master/roles/ensure-tox/tasks/main.yaml

That tries to check if tox is already installed on the system and if it cannot find a tox installation it installs it to a virtualenv and then exports the executable as a cached fact.

With Sorin's change:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/690057/39/roles/ensure-tox/tasks/main.yaml

It also allows the user to install a newer version or enforce a specific version.

There is a case with need of a few ansible versions in parallel, due to some restrictions of ansible-galaxy in current ansible-2.9 and future ansible-2.10.
Having option to install both of them and use each one separately is necessary.

tooz/drivers/redis.py.message: Don't we want to handle retry there too?

Does the connection will be automatically restablished by the client at this point?

If the connection isn't automatically restored I'm not sure to see how this retry will help to solve this issue.

Don't we need to reset the connection by reinitializing the client if we face a connection or a timeout error?

The goal of an heartbeat is to keep connections actives if I correctly understand your issue at this point we already loose the connection, isn't?

Either this method is wrongly named or we don't do the right thing.

The connection is re-established by the client. I couldn't find the root cause why redis keeps closing the connection from time to time (when used via haproxy), that is a change between ... let's say queens and train.. 

The heartbeat feature in redis-py does not solve this issue (preventing redis server closing it down).

Can't we continue with `_translate_failure` and simply catch `coordination.ToozConnectionError`
and `exceptions.RedisError`?

In this case our tenacity retry exception type caught will be against `coordination.ToozConnectionError`.

That will allow us to keep uniformity with other methods based on `_translate_failure` and will avoid the related technical debt.

If I understand correctly our code you ignored the ConnectionError to allow tenacity to catch it and then here you only handle timeouts to override `_translate_failure`, isn't?

Why we don't want to retry on timeout too?

Shouldn't we try to retry under timeout condition too?

Tooz consider timeouts and connection errors as one and same thing (ToozConnectionError) so I think our retry strategy should do the same thing too.

I see ConnectionErrors happening all over, but most interestingly, the stack trace only happens here in this heartbeat function.
Also, I didn't want to change any functionality other than retrying on ConnectionError, which is the error thrown, when the server closes down the connection.

specs/wallaby/ssl-root-ca.rst.message: remains the responsibility of the deployer
This verification should probably include a check if the server certificate or it's chain of trust are not due to expire within a defined period.

While it sounds super reasonable, I'm not sure about it. This is applicable only for self-singed ones, while we should also support user-provided ones. So I'd say it should just have a flag to:
* generate new certificate for specific service
* generate new root ca

And it's up to deployer to take care of certificates expiration date and run playbooks with specific tags to get certificates renewed.
Once certificates are all on stored on the deploy host, it should be prety easy to adjust used monitoring tooling to collect data about their expiration dates
In the case where the role is responsible for creating server certificates and the intermediate/root CA certificates are still valid, the role could generate a new cert on the deploy host.

That might be good, but I'm not sure what action should role execute if it's due - fail with error?
I don't think that ordinary debug message will be read by anybody during openstack upgrade or smth.

# Create a signed ssh key which can be validated against the CA certificate
to avoid needing to distribute all keys to all hosts.

To add to Andrew's comment about renewals, support for multiple trusted Root CA's would make Root CA renewal easier as you could trust multiple during a transition period.
Or specify the use of the "Root CA Key Update" methods with certificates OldWithOld, OldWithNew, and NewWithOld
https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4210#section-4.4
If possible you could consider using an explicit trust store for securing internal communications rather than implicit using the system trust store.

Actually I'm not sure about explicit trust store, since it means that we need to adjust literally every config file and provide path to the CA for all services, which requires pretty much effort.
So it's possible, but I'd rather start with smth and then iterate if needed.
Agreed, its a lot of work for minimal security gain and can always be retrospectively added

* The deployer may already be using signed ssh keys for access to hosts
  so any implementation should work alongside existing configuration. It
  may be necessary to investigate supporting more than one trusted CA in
  the ssh_config file.

requirements.txt.message:
IS it possible to remove pbr from requirements.txt now, or is there some tool that still requires it to be here?
It's still listed in setup.py under setup_requires, and I would have thought that would be sufficient. Notably, osprofiler (whence this patch was copied) never had pbr listed in its requirements.txt.

Reading https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0518/#rationale, I'm not exactly encouraged to proceed with a complete removal of pbr from requirements. At the very least, it may interfere with pip behavior. At the very least, it won't respect upper-constraints.

My understanding of this is that you only need to specify pbr in 'requirements.txt' if you're using it at runtime, but to use it during install you must specify it in the 'setup_requires' argument of 'setup' and assume that 'setuptools' is present and will handle this. That would make sense since it is pbr that knows to translate the contents of 'requirements.txt' and 'test-requirements.txt' files to the 'install_requires' and the 'extras["test"]' arguments of the 'setup' call. Without pbr already present, we wouldn't know even read this file.

Since we're no longer using pbr in code, I do think we can remove 'pbr' from here. I'll look at doing so in a follow-up.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Thanks; the change itself looks good.  But let's expand the commit message.  Draft text:

[quote]

TLS client verification used to be accidentally disabled in libvirt.  This was fixed in libvirt-6.10.0-1[1].  Which means, once you're using libvirt-6.10.0-1 or higher, a client certificate is mandatory during live migration with TLS.

In this case, the server certificate generated by TripleO is valid for client _and_ server:

                 Key Purpose (not critical):
                         TLS WWW Server.
                         TLS WWW Client.

So most deployments can re-use the same certificate for client and server.  Why?  Because if both migration ends points are located on the same infrastructure, it is reasonable to use the same certificate for both client and server roles.
[/quote]

Thanks to DanPB for helping me debug this.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1879477#c3
Done

This will break live migration for instances created pre 6.10 where the qemu processes created prio to this change won't have client certificates, correct? A instance stop/start would be required. Wondering if we need to add a parameter for nbd client cert verification and set it to disabled per default to not break live migration for no new deployments?

That's a good assessment and I believe this should be addressed by this related change [1]. We'll default it to false when we hit the train branch.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/785962/2

unrelated change? also now the indent is wrong

Actually it looks like adding Chassis here without modifying the above would be OK because we don't also include Chassis_Private in the tables, so Chassis *would* be conditionally monitored. But in agent.py we pass both, so I guess that means there we've always been listening for all Chassis and only our own Chassis_Private? Is that the intended behavior? Should it be something like:

 for table in set(tables).intersection({'Chassis', 'Chassis_Private'}):
     self.tables[table].condition = [['name', '==', chassis]]

or am I misunderstanding how things should work?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: This doesn't seem valid for our in tree documentation to refer to an out of tree driver. The out of tree Hyper-V driver uses os-assisted-volume-snapshots but the in tree Hyper-V driver does not? As an aside, I'm curious what's the reason for that.

Someone asked for it here: https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/nova-cinder-xena-ptg. Also, it might be an useful information as this API is about to be deprecated.

It's true that it's an out of tree driver, but this also mentions the remotefs Cinder driver, which isn't part of Nova either.

As to why the the out of tree driver has this feature and the in-tree one doesn't, we went with an out of tree driver back in 2016 as it was taking way too long to have our patches reviewed, thus missing releases on a regular basis. As the codebase diverged, it became more and more difficult for us to submit patches to both drivers, so the in-tree driver only receives critical bug fixes or simple features that are worth adding to the release notes (e.g. RBD support in Wallaby).

None of our customers use the in-tree driver, but we do keep it alive (including the CI) so that Nova continues to officially support Hyper-V. The circumstances may have changed now, but sync-ing the drivers at this point would probably require significant effort, mostly on the reviewing side.

zuul/scheduler.py.message:
Since you pushed this change up for discussion --

I think we need to keep these stats working through the whole process.  I think they're some of the most important stats, and they're likely to be used in alert systems.

Personally, I think having the executors write summary stats to the registry (maybe every 10 seconds?) or having the scheduler read the queue from zk would be acceptable ways to accomplish this.

We might need a little of both, since it makes sense for an executor to write accepting and running, but not queued.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: nova-api and nova-metadata-api ?

Do we have any bug explaining this issue or limitation ? It's hard to understand the reason of this change, and it's not clear whether this change should be implemented in the other components.

Also, I think it would make more sense to update the default value rather than dropping the thread parameter.
Done as you suggested. I believe I saw a bug opened for Nova, but couldn't find it anymore. Anyways, the nova-api logs are very clear in this regard, and there's a warning, so it should IMO be fine.

If we should force threads=1 then I still feel it is valuable to ensure threads=1 .
My suggestion here is to just change the default and show a warning message when threads>1.
This also allows users to use threads just in case the problem with threading is fixed in a future release.

This is not mandatory but if you can report a bug for nova and put a link for it then it helps people understand the reason behind this.

Hi.
The issue is simply that by default, the Debian package has threads=1, which is a working value. Unfortunately, changing it to anything else (ie: more than 1) renders nova-api completely broken (the log says: impossible to switch tread).

It doesn't make sense to update the default value, because we do not want anyone to even attempt to change the value.

This shouldn't be implemented in other components, the problem is only in Nova, others are fine with threads=32 by default.

Maybe this is related ?

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: This does not make sense now as the caller does not request live detach now, they request detach-from-all-form-of-the-domain.
this is also not valid any more so I rephrased it.

grammar nit: This reads oddly. Something like:

  both on the persistent domain and on the live domain.

or:

  on both the persistent and live domains.

would read a little better (I'd opt for the latter, personally)
(no, I don't know what grammatical rule is in play here /o\)

Originally the caller requested live detach with a flag in the function's signature. But this patch moves the logic from the callers into the detach function to decide if live detach is needed or not. 

In the past if the caller asked for a live detach but there was no device in the live domain the it made sense to tell the caller that the request was wrong. Now it does not make any sense any more as the caller only asks for detach-it-from-every-domain. So the device exists in at least one of the domains then we should not raise back. So I will follow your second suggestion.

Also see https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/770246/24/nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py#2275 that is somewhat related and led to some of the changes in this patch.

    for key in roledata:
        if roledata[key] is None:
            # Probably an incomplete stack, ignore it.
            continue
        elif nbd_tls_key in roledata[key]['config_settings']:
            nbd_tls = roledata[key][

            parameters['UseTLSTransportForNbd'] = nbd_tls
            break

We could use some comments in here to keep things straight

# This cluster of patches relates to fixing

then somewhere further down

Don't intermix the base forward vs. fix patches, keep them separate.  I would suggest even numbering them with a gap between them.

then at the end

# This patch fixes build issues related to the above patches.  Our goal is to keep

This cherry-pick is for a commit id not found in the repo.  It is likely from the original header.  You can leave this line alone, but add another line to make it extremely clear where this patch came from, use square brackets like this:

I see it in my clone of upstream systemd, did you pull the latest Jim? As for format used to capture upstream commit info, if square braces is expected this needs to be fixed in many of these.

We usually use

[commit 123456abcded upstream]

if it is a cherry pick from the official upstream repository. If it is from a fork or anything else we use

[commit 23213jk3jfaskf from <say where>]

I had missed in the commit log that these were claimed to have come from the RH fork, so I agree 100% with your concern and the error in the formatting, as demonstrated by my victimhood.

My point is that she said that she got these commits from the systemd-rhel/rhel-8 repo, so there should be a reference to the commit-id in *that* repo.  We shouldn't have to guess at the heritage of any patches.

base/systemd/centos/patches/907-sd-event.message:
The diffstats don't match

masselst@yow-masselst-lx1:~/git/systemd$ git diff --stat ddfde737b546c17e54182028153aa7f7e78804e3~ ddfde737b546c17e54182028153aa7f7e78804e3
 src/libsystemd/sd-event/sd-event.c | 245 +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++---------------------------------------------------------------------
 1 file changed, 129 insertions(+), 116 deletions(-)

You need to capture why the difference exists above the 'cherry picked' line, something like

[LZ: added....]

Jim. Agreed. The explanation would be between the upstream commit as described in the 'cherry picked' line and what we are seeing here. This is important to capture for many reasons
* to help us who are reviewing know that there are changes and thus we might want to take a closer look at those change
* to respect the original author, as their original commit is being modified so by including this it is clear that we are attributing the work to them but have modified their original work
* to help review the change if/when we update systemd to help us make sure we can safely drop the change if moving beyond the point it was cherry picked.
*...

Ideally the person cherry picking to the RH fork would have also done this if they had made changes, and so we get a history built up of changes from the original form of the commit.
Or actually I believe the comment line might go below the 'cherry picked' line. Jim, is there a preference?

I wouldn't expect her to explain differences between the rhel version and the full upstream version.  But perhaps you Linux folks have stricter standards?

I have no preference about where change explanations go, as long as they are in square brackets.

All my portings are based on systemd-rhel/rhel-8, and I have described this with [commit xxxxx from https://github.com/systemd-rhel/rhel-8/] for every patch. The explanations are based on this too.
Please check based on it (not on systemd mainline)， including all the following patches. Thanks.

oslo_privsep/comm.py.message: This was necessary to prevent a hang when a privileged call is made too soon after the daemon is SIGHUP'd. It doesn't actually fix the error, but at least it returns an error immediately rather than hanging indefinitely.

This was necessary to prevent a hang when a privileged call is made too soon after the daemon is SIGHUP'd. It doesn't actually fix the error, but at least it returns an error immediately rather than hanging indefinitely.
